INFOBOX.TITLE: Change infection probability
INFOBOX.BODY: By changing the infection probability, you can simulate the effect of introducing or relaxing preventative measures.
INFOBOX.EXAMPLE_1: "Assume that closing schools reduces the probability of infection by 10%."
INFOBOX.DESCRIPTION_1: To simulate this measure, set the slider to -10% (a reduction of 10%). By setting a start and end date, you can simulate the start date and end date of this measure.
INFOBOX.EXAMPLE_2: "Assume that reopening schools increases the probability of infection by 5%."
INFOBOX.DESCRIPTION_2: To simulate this relaxation, set the slider to +5% (an increase of 5%). By setting a start date, you can simulate the starting date of this relaxation. You can leave the end date blank to simulate the relaxation of implemented measures.

GRAPH.INFOBOX: Note: There is some missing data between 2 March 2020 and 14 April 2020. The missing data has been interpolated. For more details, please refer to the Algorithm page.
GRAPH.TITLE_PER_DAY: Number of confirmed cases per day

ALGORITHM.PRED_BODY:
The algorithm uses the SIR model: every individual has a state which is either 'susceptible', 'infectious', or 'removed'. As a first step, the data is pre-processed in order to obtain an SIR model for each province. Based on this, the curing probability and infection probability between two provinces are determined. These values can then be used in combination with the available data to arrive at a prediction.

This type of prediction algorithm is network-based: the prediction is made based on the estimated interaction between provinces. Several studies have recently been conducted that apply this principle, all with promising results.

For details on the algorithm, please refer to the adjacent article.
ALGORITHM.DATA_BODY:
The predictions displayed on the dashboard are based on publicly available data. The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (Dutch: Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu or RIVM) offers various data sources[1]. The Esri data source is the most appropriate for this project[2]. This source includes the number of reports per municipality per day, which can then be added up to arrive at a total amount per province.

A disadvantage of this source is that are several days for which data is not available. For the prediction algorithm used, it is important that the infection data is divided into provinces, but this missing data cannot be found per province on other sources. The missing data is therefore filled in by means of linear interpolation.

The data source only gives the number of new reports per day. These can also be reports of people who have been diagnosed a few days earlier, but were only entered into the system later and were not retroactively added to the correct days. This is also a disadvantage of the data source, but there are no alternative sources that can address this problem either. However, generally speaking this problem only affects a few reports and the delay is no more than two days, so this does not have a significant impact on the prediction algorithm.

After this process, all of the necessary data is available. Because the prediction algorithm uses number of new infections per day and the data source only has the cumulative number of reports available, the number of new infections is determined by taking the difference between two consecutive days.

DATA.DESCRIPTION: These tables contain the data used to make the predictions. Please note that the data has been pre-processed and may differ from the official numbers. An explanation of the pre-processing steps can be found on the Downloads page.

ABOUT.TITLE: About us
ABOUT.BODY:
This website is maintained by the Network Architectures and Services (NAS) group of the Delft University of Technology. The NAS group belongs to the Quantum and Computer Engineering Department in the faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science (EEMCS).

NAS educates and conducts research in the broad area of complex networks, ranging from man-made infrastructures such as data communications and energy networks, to biological, brain, social and financial networks. The emphasis lies on understanding network characteristics as well as the processes running on top of the network.

The prediction algorithm used on this website is based on a paper published by members of the NAS group, Network-inference-based prediction of the COVID-19 epidemic outbreak in the Chinese province Hubei. More information about the algorithm can be found on the Algorithm page.

MAINTAIN.TITLE: Website maintainers
MAINTAIN.BODY:
This website has been adapted for the NAS group by two masters students, Brian Chang and Liufei Yang. The website is also maintained by two members of the NAS group, Long Ma and Massimo Achterberg.

The maintainers of the website would like to thank Prof.dr.ir. Piet Van Mieghem and the other members of the NAS group for providing input and feedback during the development of this website.

ORIGINAL.TITLE: Original creators

The client for the project was Dr. Huijuan Wang and their coach was Dr. Claudia Hauff. The NAS group would like to express gratitude to the original creators for allowing us to adapt their work:

ABOUT.TITLE: About the data
ABOUT.BODY: On this page, you can download the data used for prediction on this website. Please note that this data has been pre-processed, so some data can be different from the official numbers reported by the RIVM (Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu). An explanation of the pre-processing steps follows.

CUMULATIVE.TITLE: Cumulative confirmed cases per province per day
CUMULATIVE.BODY:
The RIVM reports the cumulative number of confirmed cases per municipality which we sum per province to find the cumulative number of confirmed cases per province per day. However, data is not available for some municipalities between 2 March 2020 and 14 April 2020. For the prediction algorithm used, it is important that the confirmed cases are divided into provinces, but this missing data cannot be found per province on other sources either.
The following pre-processing steps were taken:

  • If the cumulative number of confirmed cases is missing on 2 March 2020 (the date on which the data begins), it is set to 0 for this day.

  • If the cumulative number of confirmed cases is missing on any other day, it is filled in through linear interpolation. When linear interpolation results in a non-integer value, it is cast to an integer with a floor function. For example: assume on 1 April there are 0 confirmed cases, on 2 April and 3 April the data is missing, and on 4 April there are 4 confirmed cases. Linear interpolation results in 1.33 cases on 2 April and 2.67 cases on 3 April. Since these are non-integer values, they are cast to integers using a floor function. This finally results in 1 case on 2 April and 2 cases on 3 April.

For each municipality, any missing data is first filled in using the steps described above. Afterwards, the data is summed per province to arrive at the cumulative number of confirmed cases per province per day.

NEW.TITLE: New confirmed cases per province per day
NEW.BODY:
The RIVM reports the cumulative number of confirmed cases, so to find the number of new confirmed cases per day, the difference between two days is taken for each province. On 2 March 2020 (the date on which the data begins), the number of new confirmed cases is equal to the cumulative number of confirmed cases on that day. For the remaining days, the number of new confirmed cases is found by subtracting the cumulative number of confirmed cases on the previous day from the cumulative number of confirmed cases on the current day.

On some days, the number of new confirmed cases is negative, which indicates that the cumulative number of confirmed cases decreases between two days. If the data from previous days was accidentally too high, after correction the new number of confirmed cases can be negative. On the days where the number of new confirmed cases is negative, it is set to 0.

INHABITANTS.TITLE: Number of inhabitants per province (as of last noted date)
INHABITANTS.BODY: The last noted date is the last date on which the number of inhabitants of any province has changed. It is possible that the number of inhabitants has not been updated for every province on this day. For provinces which do not have an updated number of inhabitants, the most recent estimate is used instead.
